title: Wrigley Gum Empire Heir Sells Aspen Mansion for $30 Million; William Wrigley Jr. sold the roughly 7,500-square-foot, mountain-style home to a trust tied to the president of a Caterpillar dealer
text:
The buyer is a trust tied to Texas residents Corinna Holt Richter and Joseph Brian Richter Jr., according to property records. Ms. Richter is the great-great-granddaughter of Benjamin Holt, who developed one of the first commercially successful tractors that moved on tracks rather than wheels. His company was one of two that merged to become the construction machinery giant Caterpillar. She is president of Holt Cat, a Caterpillar heavy equipment and engine dealer, according to her LinkedIn profile.

Mr. Wrigley and the Richters couldn't immediately be reached for comment.

The Aspen mansion has been on the market since June asking $32.25 million, according to the listings website Zillow. The property last traded in 2004 for $8.4 million, according to property records.

The mountain-style home was built in 1998 and renovated in 2019, according to the listing with Riley Warwick and Joshua Saslove of Douglas Elliman. Spanning about 7,500 square feet, it has four bedrooms, a gym, a game room and a bar. There's also a wraparound outdoor deck and a hot tub. The property has views of Aspen and Buttermilk Mountain and direct access to the Rio Grande Trail, according to the listing.

Mr. Wrigley is listing two other adjacent parcels of land, asking $26.875 million apiece, records show.

Mr. Wrigley is the former chief executive of the Wrigley Company, the chewing-gum company founded in the late 19th century by his great-grandfather. The company was sold to Mars for $23 billion in 2008. More recently, Mr. Wrigley did a stint as the chief executive of the marijuana company Parallel.

Chris Souki of Coldwell Banker Mason Morse represented the buyers.
